Situation1: The meeting is the final discussion before major decisions are locked in.
Expectation2: Providing spiritual guidance and counseling to community members
Situation2: A long-time congregant requested a private meeting soon because of mounting family stress.
Story: I stared at my phone, the calendar app open, two reminders blinking at me. In ten minutes, my team’s final meeting before the project launch would begin. As a colleague, I was expected to be there, to contribute, to show my commitment. My manager had emphasized how crucial everyone’s input was for this last discussion. But just as I was about to close my laptop and head to the conference room, my phone buzzed again—a message from Brother Ahmed, a long-time congregant. He sounded desperate, asking if I could meet him soon. His family was in crisis, and he needed spiritual guidance, someone to listen and help him find peace. As an imam, I knew how much he relied on me, how important it was to be present for my community in their moments of need. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations pressing in from both sides. I could feel the tension building inside me, torn between my responsibility to my colleagues and my duty to my congregation, knowing that whichever path I chose, I would be letting someone down.
